JournalInfo.JournalTitle: International Journal of Multimedia Information Retrieval

ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: A novel framework for CBCD using integrated color and acoustic features

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Computer Science and Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Most studies in content-based video copy detection (CBCD) concentrate on visual signatures, while only very few efforts are made to exploit audio features. The audio data, if present, is an essential source of a video; hence, the integration of visual-acoustic fingerprints significantly improves the copy detection performance. Based on this aspect, we propose a new framework, which jointly employs color-based visual features and audio fingerprints for detecting the duplicate videos. The proposed framework incorporates three stages: First, a novel visual fingerprint based on spatio-temporal dominant color features is generated; Second, mel-frequency cepstral coefficients are extracted and compactly represented as acoustic signatures; Third, the resultant multimodal signatures are jointly used for the CBCD task, by employing combination rule and weighting strategies. The results of experiments on TRECVID 2008 and 2009 datasets, demonstrate the improved efficiency of the proposed framework compared to the reference methods against a wide range of video transformations.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Due to the exponential growth of multimedia technologies, numerous pirated videos are proliferating on the Internet and causing huge piracy as well as copyright issues. For instance, the latest Canadian Motion Picture Distributors Association (CMPDA)-2011 report alarms that, 133 million pirated movies are watched in Canada in 2010 [1]. Hence, video copy detection techniques are very much essential for copyright management, since they restrict the downloading as well as distribution of illegal contents on the Internet. In general, a video copy/ pirate video is a distorted video sequence derived from the master/ database video by applying several video editing and transformations such as noise, cropping, zooming, and caption insertions.

Digital watermarking and content-based video copy detection (CBCD) techniques are widely used in the literature to detect video copies [2]. The watermarking approach embeds an identifier (watermark) into the master video before distribution and checks the identifier in the query video to detect whether it is copyrighted or not. The alternative CBCD techniques utilize video fingerprints extracted from the content-based features to assess a video copy [3, 4]. The key challenge of a CBCD system is to provide accurate matching of a copy clip with its master video, even though the copy clip is heavily distorted [5]. Due to the fragile nature of watermarks, the complementary CBCD techniques are emerging as primary tools for dealing with digital video piracy and thus, generated a great deal of research interest recently.

In addition to copyright protection, CBCD techniques can be employed to compute the accurate frame alignments of the pirate video with the master sequence [6]. Followed by spatio-temporal frame alignments of the pirate content with the master video, CBCD schemes are also useful to estimate the geometric distortions present in the pirate video [7].

Section2.Heading: Related work
Section2.Para: In the CBCD literature, considerable efforts are made to propose effective video signatures and efficient similarity matching techniques. Early research on CBCD could be roughly classified into two groups, namely global and local descriptor techniques [8]. For example, global descriptors such as the ordinal measure [9], and color histograms [5] summarize the global statistics of low level features of frames. Though, global features are compact and perform better for frame-level transformations; yet, they are less robust against region-based attacks such as caption insertion, picture-in-picture, and cropping.

Due to the limited capability of global descriptors, many researchers introduced local descriptors, which compute a set of interest points to facilitate local matching. For example, SIFT [10] and SURF [11] descriptors are very popular in this field, which are more robust than global descriptors in handling several video manipulations. However, local descriptors are computationally expensive and require multidimensional structures for indexing features.

There are notable works in the literature on CBCD problem, which utilize only visual signatures for detecting illegal videos. For example, Chiu et al. [12] utilized ordinal signatures and proposed a probabilistic framework to transform the copy detection task into a shortest path problem. Although, this method is efficient, the ordinal signature they use, limits the resistance to region-based attacks such as zooming and pattern insertion. Furthermore, the authors experimented on a limited set of distortions such as brightness enhancement, speed change, and resize. However, the video modifications such as noise, pattern insertion, zoom in, and color change are not tackled in their study.

Recently, Küçüktunç et al. [3] presented a copy detection framework by employing MPEG-7 descriptors, facial shot mapping and activity subsequence matching techniques, which is less effective against complex transformations such as camcording and picture-in-picture. Sarkar et al. [5] designed a duplicate video detection system using color layout descriptors and proposed a non-metric distance measure to search efficiently in the high-dimensional space. However, this scheme may score inaccurate results, if the query video contains portions of multiple master video sequences. Chiu and Wang [8] introduced a time-series linear search (TLS) method, which combines compact video signatures derived from min-hash theory and efficient fingerprint generation process based on heap operations for detecting illegal video sequences.

On other hand, though audio content is an essential information source of a video; yet, only very few attempts are made to detect video copies using acoustic signatures. For instance, Itoh et al. [13] utilized acoustic power features for their copy detection task. Though, this method scores better detection rates; still, it is computationally expensive. Anguera et al. [14] designed a multimodal video copy detection system, which combines the visual fingerprints extracted from luminance variations as well as the audio signatures derived from spectral coefficients. However, this method fails to provide better accuracy for region-based attacks such as logo insertions and subtitles.

Saracoğlu et al. [15] presented a framework by employing coarse visual-audio fingerprints for identifying the video copies. Although, the performance of this method is reasonably good, still it is less effective against video attacks such as picture-in-picture, due to the limitations of the global descriptors. Moreover, the authors combined the audio-visual fingerprints in a simplified manner based on decision scores, which may not guarantee a stable performance for all the cases.

To summarize, numerous state-of-the-art CBCD techniques are focusing only on visual fingerprints, though the audio content is a significant information source of a video sequence. In addition, in most of the duplication cases, the audio content is less affected compared to the visual counterpart [15]. Therefore, promising frameworks employing both the visual and acoustic signatures in a unified manner are needed for detecting video copies, while this research field is ongoing one.

Section2.Heading: Motivation and contributions
Section2.Para: If audio data is available, then the joint utilization of visual-audio fingerprints for the CBCD task, not only enhances the copy detection performance, but also widens the coverage to more number of video transformations. Based on this aspect, we propose a novel framework for the CBCD problem, which employs the new visual fingerprints derived from dominant color descriptors (DCDs) [16], denoted as Spatio-Temporal DCDs and robust acoustic signatures extracted from mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs) [17], in an integrated manner for identifying the duplicate video sequences.

More precisely, we first introduce a new DCDs extraction algorithm known as, RGB-Feature Image Computation, which efficiently extracts the DCDs of the given image, when compared to the existing color clustering-based techniques. From another perspective, past studies on DCDs, exploit only the global description of the dominant color features existing in the spatial domain for describing the given image. However, such global color descriptions may not be adequate to provide the precise localization of dominant colors in an image.

To solve this discrepancy, we propose a novel visual fingerprint denoted as, Spatio-Temporal DCDs, which effectively characterizes the region-based dominant color features and temporal color statistics present in the given video sequence.

Further, we present a Decision Fusion technique, which jointly exploits both the visual-audio fingerprints for detecting the video copies, by means of utilizing the combination rule and weight factor strategies.

Section1.Heading: Proposed CBCD framework
Section1.Para:
The overview of proposed CBCD framework is shown in Fig. 1 and the relevant notations are described in Table 1. Precisely, the proposed framework consists of two main stages: off-line (Master video processing) and online (query video processing). In the off-line stage, visual fingerprints based on dominant color features and audio fingerprints based on MFCCs are extracted from the master video contents. Specifically, the extraction of visual fingerprints is detailed in Sect. 3 and the audio signatures generation is described in Sect. 4. The resultant visual and audio fingerprints are stored in the fingerprint database.

In the online stage, when a query clip is given, resampling technique is used, to synchronize the query and master video frame rates. From the query video, visual and acoustic fingerprints are extracted as described in Sects. 3 and 4. After this step, the resultant acoustic-visual fingerprints are matched separately and the individual mapping results are combined, to obtain the copy detection results, which is illustrated in Sect. 5. Section 6 describes the experiments setup of the proposed CBCD system followed by the detection results in terms of PR metrics. Finally, the conclusions and the future work mentioned in Sect. 7.

Section1.Heading: Visual fingerprints extraction
Section1.Para:
Dominant color descriptor (DCD) of MPEG-7 standard effectively describes the color information present in an image, by capturing the dominant (or) representative colors from that image [16, 18]. More specifically, DCD compactly represents the prominent color distribution present in an image with a small number of dominant colors and their relative distribution. In MPEG-7 standard, DCD is defined as, 1
$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{DCD} = \{ \{c_i, p_i\}, v_i, s\} ,\ i \in [1:m], \end{aligned}$$
DCD =
{
{
c i
,
p i
}
,
v i
, s }
,
i ∈
[ 1 : m ]
,
Here,
$$c_i$$
c i
represents 3-D color vector and
$$p_i$$
p i
indicates the percentage of distribution of each dominant color [18] and
$$m$$
m
represents the total dominant colors of an image. Color variance
$$v$$
v
and spatial coherency
$$s$$
s
are optional fields, which precisely characterize the color distribution in color space and spatial domains, respectively [18].

In the past studies, color clustering algorithm such as generalized lloyd algorithm (GLA) [19] is widely utilized to extract DCDs from an image [18, 20]. However, GLA suffers due to these limitations: (a) It is computationally intensive and (b) The efficiency of GLA mainly depends upon the initial specifications such as number of clusters, distance, and centroid.

To solve this problem, a novel DCD extraction scheme, denoted as RGB-Feature Image Computation is presented, which efficiently extracts the dominant colors from an image. More precisely, the proposed CBCD system expands the frequency imaging method introduced by Kashiwagu and Oe [21] and derives a novel DCD extraction scheme called as RGB-Feature Image Computation algorithm. Without the loss of generality, RGB color space is employed in the proposed framework to compute RGB-Feature Image, which extracts dominant colors and their relative distribution present in an image. The RGB-Feature Image computation algorithm given in Fig. 2, illustrates the steps used to compute the RGB-Feature Image from the given image/ region.
Fig. 2
RGB-Feature Image computation algorithm

On the other hand, most studies in DCD extraction exploit spatial information and provide only the global description of dominant colors in an image. For example, Deng et al. [18] and Yang et al. [20] extract dominant colors from the whole image/frame and utilize global description of colors to characterize an image. However, such global color descriptions may be inadequate to obtain the precise localization of dominant colors in an image. In practice, many video or movie scenes exist with same dominant color patterns; though, they have entirely different contents. For instance, the images given in Fig. 3a, b shows the scenario, in which global description of dominant colors is same irrespective of their contents; hence, in this case, global color description fails to differentiate these two images. Therefore, region-wise distribution information of dominant colors is essential in many applications such as content-based image retrieval and indexing.
Fig. 3
Sample images having same global description of dominant colors irrespective of their different contents. a Image-1 having two horizontal lines with gray level 200 and background with gray level 50. b Image-2 having two cross lines with gray level 200 and background with gray level 50

From another perspective, it is to be noted that, Consecutive images in a video sequence have very similar color statistics [22]. Thus, we can exploit the color similarity existing in the temporal domain for efficiently describing the color information of a video. On the other hand, we need extract on average 3–8 dominant colors to describe an image [23]. Hence minimum number of DCDs extracted from a video
$$V_i$$
V i
of size
$$N$$
N
frames is
$$N\times 3$$
N × 3
, and size of the visual signature becomes approximately
$$N\times 3\times 4$$
N × 3 × 4
(i.e., 4 digits/ DCD). If size of N increases, the computational cost also increases. However, compact visual signatures are essential to enhance the detection accuracy of the CBCD system.

To tackle the above-mentioned issues, a new visual signature, denoted as Spatio-Temporal DCDs is presented, which efficiently characterizes the color information of a given image. More specifically, Spatio-Temporal DCDs extract region-based dominant color features and exploit color statistics present in the consecutive frames, to generate efficient visual fingerprints from the video sequences. Spatio-Temporal DCDs computation algorithm is given in Fig. 4, which details the steps used to calculate the Spatio-Temporal DCDs signatures of the video sequences. Experiments are conducted with different block sizes ranging from 2 to 6 for Spatio-Temporal DCD extraction. Since, 2
$$\times $$
×
2 blocks provide better detection accuracy, hence they are utilized in the proposed CBCD task. Figure 5 illustrates Spatio-Temporal DCDs extraction from the sample frames on a 2
$$\times $$
×
2 blocks.
Fig. 4
Spatio-Temporal DCDs extraction algorithm
Fig. 5
Spatio-Temporal DCDs extraction. a A video clip with three frames partitioned into 2
$$\times $$
×
2 blocks. b RGB-Feature Image computed for each block. c Spatial-Temporal DCDs computed for each block with time series

To emphasize the benefits of the proposed Spatio-Temporal DCDs scheme, we evaluated two sets of experiments namely, spatial DCDs and Spatio-Temporal DCDs extraction. In [23], we employed spatial DCDs extraction scheme, in which DCDs extracted from RGB-Feature Images are considered as visual signatures of video sequences. Table 2 shows total DCDs extracted by both the Spatial and Spatio-Temporal DCDs methods from different video sequences. Table 2 results proves that, the proposed Spatio-Temporal DCDs scheme, noticeably reduces the total dominant color features required to describe the given video (i.e., up to 59 %). Therefore, in the proposed framework, Spatio-Temporal DCDs scheme is employed for the CBCD task, which is more compact and profitable compared to the conventional spatial DCDs extraction methods. In this way, the proposed Spatio-Temporal DCDs extraction algorithm not only reduces the computational complexity of the feature extraction process but also minimizes the clustering related overheads.

Section1.Heading: Audio fingerprints generation
Section1.Para: In this proposed framework, we employ MFCCs to derive the acoustic fingerprints from the video contents. MFCCs are highly robust and discriminative spectral features, thus they are widely used in video indexing and segmentation methods [24]. In the mel-frequency cepstrum, the frequency bands are equally spaced on mel-scale, which closely approximates response of the human hearing systems with respect to different frequencies [17, 25]. This frequency warping allows better representation of sound signals in automatic speech recognition applications. Further, MFCCs represent perceptual feature of the audio signals very well. Therefore, it is quite difficult to alter MFCCs, even for manipulations such as mp3 compression. Due to these reasons, we utilize perceptually robust MFCCs to extract audio signatures of video contents, in the proposed framework.

Section2.Heading: MFCCs extraction
Section2.Para:
The block diagram of audio fingerprints generation is shown in Fig. 6. which is based on MFCC features. More precisely, first the audio signal is down sampled to 22,050 Hz, to reduce the size of data to be processed. In case of 10–30 ms of window length, the magnitude of audio spectrum behaves almost stationary; hence, the downsampled audio signal is segmented into 11.60 ms windows using Hamming windowing with an overlap factor of 76 % [26].
Fig. 6
Block diagram of audio fingerprints generation

The most important perceptual audio features exist in the frequency domain [17, 25]. Therefore, spectral representation of each analysis window is computed by applying Fourier transformations. Let
$$f_i$$

Finally, the Mel-frequency cepstrum is computed as the DCT of the T filter outputs as, 7
$$\begin{aligned} c(n)= \sum \limits _{m=1}^{T} \Psi (m) \mathrm{cos} \left[ \frac{\pi n(m-0.5)}{T}\right] , \ \ \ 1\le n \le T \end{aligned}$$

Equation (7) typically results in 24–40 MFCC terms. For speech signals, the first 13 cepstrum coefficients are often utilized [28]; hence, we considered first 13 MFCC features for the proposed CBCD task.

The MFCCs calculation in Eq. (7) results in an F
$$\times $$
×
N matrix, where F rows indicate the number of frames and N consists of 13 MFCC features extracted from a frame. Then, singular value decomposition (SVD) is applied, to effectively summarize the MFCC feature matrix. Precisely, the F
$$\times $$
×
N matrix is decomposed as
$$S= U\sum V^T$$
S = U ∑
V T
, where S is F
$$\times $$
×
N input matrix to be summarized, U is F
$$\times $$
×
F orthogonal matrix,
$$\sum $$
∑
is an F
$$\times $$
×
N diagonal matrix consisting of the singular values of S and V is N
$$\times $$
×
N orthogonal matrix. Generally few larger singular values are utilized to provide the summarization of matrix S, hence six to eight singular values are employed in the proposed CBCD framework.

Further, enhancing the robustness of the proposed audio signatures against various media manipulations such as mp3 and band compressions, is very much essential for the copy detection task. By keeping this aspect in mind, normalization technique is exploited in the proposed CBCD system. Precisely, we exploit normalized singular values as the acoustic fingerprints for the given CBCD task, which are computed as given by, 8
$$\begin{aligned} \Delta _i = \frac{S_i - S_{\text{ min }}}{S_{\text{ max }}-S_{\text{ min }}} \end{aligned}$$
Δ i

, respectively. Figure 7 shows the normalized singular value curves of the master and copied videos, in which the duplicate video is created by applying mp3 compression at a bit rate of 64 kbps.
Fig. 7
Curves showing similarity between the normalized singular values of master and duplicate video sequences
The curves plotted in Fig. 7 indicate a very high similarity between the master and duplicate video contents; hence, prove the perceptual robustness of the proposed audio fingerprints.

Section1.Heading: Fusing visual–audio fingerprints
Section1.Para:
In the proposed CBCD framework, two strategies are employed for fusing visual-audio fingerprints namely, combination rule and weighting factor to detect duplicate video sequences. The purpose of the combination rule is to choose the best matching result, by integrating the independent visual and audio content similarity matches. Further, in some duplication/copy cases, the audio content may be unavailable, either partially or completely destroyed; hence, weight factors are set to visual and audio fingerprints, to indicate their reasonable contribution in the similarity matching task. Figure 8 indicates the flowchart illustrating the fusion of visual-audio fingerprints. The similarity matching of visual and acoustic fingerprints and the fusion technique are detailed below.
Fig. 8
The flowchart showing fusion of visual-audio fingerprints

|

Section2.Heading: Decision fusion
Section2.Para:
The similarity results from visual-audio fingerprints are combined to detect video copies using the combination rule given by, 16
$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{DS}_{\text{ fin }} = W \times \mathrm{DS}_{\text{ vis }} + (1-W) \times \mathrm{DS}_{\text{ aud }} \end{aligned}$$
DS
fin
= W ×
DS
vis
+
( 1 - W )
×
DS
aud
where,
$$\mathrm{DS}_{\text{ fin }}$$
DS
fin
is the final similarity distance and W is the weighting factor. In the proposed framework, the visual and audio weight factors are empirically set as 0.65 and 0.35, respectively. Thus, the final similarity distance
$$\mathrm{DS}_{\text{ fin }}$$
DS
fin
between the master video
$$\mathrm{MV}$$
MV
and query clip QV is given by, 17
$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{DS}_{\text{ fin }}(\mathrm{MV,QV}) = 0.65 \times \mathrm{DS}_{\text{ vis }} + 0.35 \times \mathrm{DS}_{\text{ aud }} \end{aligned}$$
DS

)

Section1.Heading: Experimental setup and results
Section1.Para: The experimental setup of the proposed CBCD system including master database and query dataset construction followed by the detection results is illustrated as follows.

Section2.Heading: Master database and query dataset construction
Section2.Para:
The proposed method is evaluated on TRECVID Sound & Vision data set [29], which is widely popular in the CBCD domain ([3]). Precisely, the master database comprises 40 hours of TRECVID-2008 Sound & Vision data, plus another 60 h of TRECVID-2009 Sound & Vision data, which covers a wide variety of contents. All the video sequences are transformed into the uniform format: 352
$$\times $$
×
288 pixels and 15 fps. Resampling procedure is employed to synchronize the frame rates of master and query video clips. For example, 2 s query clip with 60 fps becomes a 240-frame sequence after implementing the resampling procedure.

Eighteen video manipulations listed in Table 3 are considered in the proposed CBCD framework, which commonly occur in illegal video contents. Figure 9 illustrates all the transformations with some example frames, which are extracted from the transformed query video sequences. Thirty video sequences are randomly selected from the master database, where the duration of these clips vary between 32–45 s. Five video clips, collected from Open Video Project [30] are used as non-reference data, to test false positives. The eighteen types of transformations listed in Table 3 are applied to the query dataset for generating final query video clips. The resulting 630 (35
$$\times $$
×
18) video sequences are used as query clips for the proposed copy detection task. Each query clip is used to detect the corresponding video sequence in the master database.
Fig. 9
Example frames extracted from the transformed query videos

30 % rotation and pattern insertion
T18
Combination of 8
20 % noise, 25 % blurring, 15 % brightness, color change,
pattern insertion, moving caption, fast forward and 20 % zoom

To measure the detection accuracy of the proposed scheme, we used standard metrics given by, 18
$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Precision} = \mathrm{TP} / (\mathrm{TP} + \mathrm{FP}) \end{aligned}$$
Precision = TP / ( TP + FP )
19
$$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Recall} =\mathrm{TP} / (\mathrm{TP} +\mathrm{FN}) \end{aligned}$$
Recall = TP / ( TP + FN )
True positives (TP) are positive examples correctly labeled as positives. False positives (FP) refer to negative examples incorrectly labeled as positives and False negatives (FN) refer to positive examples incorrectly labeled as negatives.

Section2.Heading: Accuracy comparison
Section2.Para:
Hua et al. method [method (4)] uses ordinal measure, which is one of the widely used visual signatures in the CBCD domain [31]. It is implemented as follows: Video frames are partitioned into 3
$$\times $$
×
3 blocks and the average intensities of respective blocks are computed. From the block intensities, a 9-D ordinal signature reflecting the frame’s relative intensity distribution is computed. Then the temporal shape of ordinal signatures is calculated and consequently sequence shape similarity algorithm is used to detect the duplicate video sequences.

Itoh et al. method [method (5)] utilizes acoustic power-based fingerprints for the CBCD task and it is implemented as follows: First, power of the audio signals are calculated using sliding window scheme and acoustical power envelopes are generated using power vs. time sequences. From the power envelopes, the significant points denoting local minimum/maximum values are extracted and matched using dynamic programming for the copy detection task.

Anguera et al. method [method (6)] employs visual signatures derived from Hue-luminance variations and audio fingerprints extracted from MFCC features for identifying the copied video sequences, which is implemented as follows: First the input signal is converted to HSV color space. Then, HV histograms of frames are calculated and consecutively compared in the temporal domain to generate visual fingerprints. On the other hand, from the downsampled audio signal, 24 MFCCs including cepstrum derivatives are employed as acoustic signatures for the CBCD task. After this step, both the visual and audio fingerprints are matched separately using L1-norm distance to detect the video copies.

Section2.Heading: Detection performance
Section2.Para:
Table 4 lists the Precision (P) and Recall (R) rates of six compared methods for T1–T6 transformations. This category includes random noise, blurring, rotation, brightness change, flip, and color change. The bold font indicates the highest precision and recall scores in the table.

Methods (2) and (5) generally score better results, in terms of good PR rates compared to the methods (1) and (4). This is because, audio fingerprints are less affected by visual attacks such as blurring, rotation, and brightness change. The recall rate of method (1) declines sharply for the color change attack. The reason is, the changes in the color spectrum, significantly affects the resultant DCDs-based visual signatures. However, due to the joint utilization of MFCCs and DCDs for the CBCD task, proposed method (3) gains more robust performance compared to the reference methods for T1–T6 transformations.

Hua et al. method [method (4)] scores well for brightness change type. However, method (4) yields poor precision rates for the flipping category. This is because, the block intensities are much affected by mirroring the contents, which may significantly alter the resultant ordinal signatures. Anguera et al. method [method (6)] gives better precision and recall scores for T3 category (rotation type); yet, it fails to provide good results for random noise type, because luminance values vary widely after applying gaussian noise.

Anguera et al. method [method (6)] gives better PR rates for all T1–T6 transformations compared to all other methods, except method (3). However, the proposed multifeatures based CBCD method [(i.e., method (3)] outperforms method (6) by significantly enhancing the detection accuracy in terms of 15 increase in precision rates and 12 % improvement in recall rates. The reason is, though the spatio-temporal DCDs and MFCCs-based audio signatures have their own advantages and limitations, they complement each other very well; hence, the integrated utilization of these two robust features results in consistence performance of method (3) compared to all other methods. The detection results of method (3), shown in Table IV provide a good evidence to support this viewpoint.

Method (4) scores very poor results for pattern insertion and moving caption types in terms of low recall rates. The reason is that, the method (4) generates very different video signatures for master and query clips after inserting text patterns or moving captions. Even the shape similarity algorithm cannot compensate for the large differences between the query and master video signatures; hence results in poor recall rates. Anguera et al. method [(method (6)] yields low precision rates for moving caption and pattern insertion types compared to the proposed method (3). This is due to the limited capability of global descriptors, which are less robust against region based attacks. Hua et al. method [(method (4)] gives poor precision rates for cropping transformation. This is because, cropping inserts black borders on both sides, which leads to lot of false positives. However, the proposed method (3) yields better PR rates compared to the reference methods, due to the joint utilization of robust audio features and visual signatures.

For slow motion and fast forward types, methods (1)–(3) utilize resampling technique to synchronize the master and duplicate video contents; hence these methods achieve high detection accuracy compared to other reference methods. On the other hand, for slow motion and fast forward categories, methods (4)–(6) match the two video sequences directly without resampling; hence, result in low PR rates.

Table 6 lists the copy detection results of six compared methods for T13–T18 types of video transformations, which include mp3, single, multiband compressions and combination of multiple visual attacks. The recall rate of Itoh et al. method [(method (5)] declines sharply for mp3 compression type. This is because, the acoustical power envelopes substantially vary after applying mp3 compression. Yet, our methods [methods (2) and (3)] using MFCCs are less affected in this category, due to the robust nature of MFCCs-based audio fingerprints. Method (6) yields nearly same accuracy rates for all T7–T12 types compared to the proposed method (3). Yet, mp3 compression has limited impact on robust MFCCs, hence method (3) noticeably reduces false positives and achieves improved detection accuracy when compared to method (6).

Anguera et al. method [method (6)] performs well for single and multiband compression types; still, it scores poor for combined attacks. This is because, adding the gaussian noise and changing color spectrum would substantially change the luminance values, which results in low PR rates.

From Table 6 results, it is observed that, the performance of Hua et al. method [method (4)] severely degrades for T16 and T17 categories in terms of low precision rates. The reason is, noise and pattern insertions generate very different signatures for master and duplicate video sequences; hence, more number of false positives are retrieved from the master dataset, which results in low precision rates. Itoh et al. method [(method (5)] generally scores well for all five transformations except for multiband compression type in terms of low recall values. This is because, entirely different local minimum/ maximum significant points are produced from the power envelopes of query and master contents after applying multiband compression type of modifications.

Among all the methods, method (3) and (6) achieve better detection results for all T13–T18 types. However, because of the combined utilization of spatio-temporal dominant color features and spectral signatures, method (3) is more accurate and provides better PR rates when compared to method (6). The accuracy rates of method (3) shown in Table VI are evident to support this viewpoint.

Summary: The experimental results indicate that, the proposed multifeatures based method [method (3)] consistently outperforms the reference methods, for all eighteen types of video transformations. The integrated usage of two complementary features, namely, spatio-temporal DCDs and MFCCs to detect the duplicate videos, is the exact reason for this effective performance of method (3). Further, the experimental results also prove that, the combination of two complementary features in method (3) not only improves the detection accuracy, but also widens the coverage to more number of transformations.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In this paper, a novel framework, employing two different video fingerprints namely, spatio-temporal dominant color features and MFCCs is presented for detecting the duplicate video sequences. Experimental results indicate that the proposed method consistently outperforms the reference methods, by achieving better precision and recall rates. Further, the proposed framework can be used in applications such as content-based video retrieval and indexing.

Our future target will focus on improving the robustness of the proposed method against complicated transformations such as camcording, strong encoding, picture-inside-picture, mix with speech and the very complex ones. For camcording attacks, if local descriptors are combined with the color features, the efficiency of the proposed system could be enhanced.
